item.title: Feature: A Dream of Secular Utopia in ISIS’ Backyard
item.description: At a college in Kurdish Syria, Rojava tries to train its future leaders.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: WES ENZINNA
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students attending class at the Mesopotamian Social Sciences Academy in Qamishli, Rojava’s de facto capital.

item.title: Obama Defends Presence at Climate Change Talks While Syria War Rages
item.description: If global temperatures continue to increase at their current pace, the president said, much of the United States’ spending would have to go toward addressing the consequences.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: President Obama with leaders of five island nations in Paris on Tuesday. Mr. Obama said that even small dots on the map deserved to be heard in international climate talks.

item.title: Lebanon Exchanges Prisoners With Qaeda Affiliate in Syria
item.description: The Lebanese government released 25 prisoners, including 17 women and children, in exchange for 16 Lebanese servicemen held by the Nusra Front.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: The relatives of 16 Lebanese soldiers in Beirut, Lebanon, on Tuesday. The soldiers were held for over a year by the Nusra Front in Syria.

item.title: U.S. Increases Special Operations Forces Fighting ISIS in Iraq
item.description: The expanded force will include about 50 soldiers who will work with Syrian, Arab and Kurdish forces battling militants with the Islamic State.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: For Survivors of Paris Attacks, Mental Scars May Outlast Wounds
item.description: Most of the wounded and their families, and a large number of medical personnel, are receiving psychological support for emotional trauma.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Djamel Cheboub was shot three times outside La Belle Équipe, a cafe, during the Paris attacks.

item.title: Young Palestinian Women Adopt Unfamiliar Role in Seeking to Become Killers
item.description: Where previous outbursts of violence mostly involved men, 15 women have tried, or are accused of trying, to stab Israeli soldiers or civilians since an uprising began in October.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and RAMI NAZZAL
item.media:description: Mourners at the funeral of Dania al-Husseini, 17, in the West Bank city of Hebron, in October. Dania was shot dead by Israeli security officers who said she had brandished a knife.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Discontent Over Migrants Takes a Toll on East German City
item.description: The arrival of hundreds of thousands of refugees in Germany has revived weekly rallies in Dresden against Muslims and the government of Chancellor Angela Merkel.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Supporters of Pegida marked the movement's first birthday in Dresden, Germany, in October.

item.title: Indonesia Cites Resetting of Circuit Breaker in 2014 AirAsia Crash
item.description: The move led to a series of electronic failures that caused the pilots to lose control of the plane before it fell into the Java Sea, killing all 162 people aboard.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: A section of the recovered tail of AirAsia Flight 8501 in January.

item.title: Eldar Ryazanov, Russian Film Director Known for His Satire, Dies at 88
item.description: Mr. Ryazanov used the absurdities of everyday life in the Soviet Union and in the post-Gorbachev era to become one of Russia’s most popular directors and screenwriters.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:description: Eldar Ryazanov was one of Russia’s most popular film directors and screenwriters.

item.title: Israel’s Ban of an Islamic Group Carries Risk
item.description: Israel has banned the Northern Branch of the Islamic Movement in Israel, a move that denies crucial social services to Arabs living in northern Israel.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: China's Fitful Economic Reforms
item.description: Despite the I.M.F.'s elevation of the renminbi, the Chinese government has a long way to go on the path to a market economy.
item.dc:creator: ESWAR PRASAD

item.title: Jabugo Journal: Spain’s Prized Ibérico Hams Can’t Cure Fast Enough for China
item.description: With a passion for pork products, and rising incomes, Chinese consumers have entered the market for Spanish hams with gusto.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Laura Leon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ibérico hams suspended from the ceiling at Cinco Jotas in Jabugo, Spain. A single leg of the finest ham from Cinco Jotas — weighing almost 18 pounds — costs about $670 in Spain. In the United States, the price is about double.

item.title: Sinosphere: Amid Smog Wave, an Artist Molds a Potent Symbol of Beijing’s Pollution
item.description: Armed with a vacuum and red clay, “Brother Nut” sucked up dust from around the capital’s landmarks to create a solid brick of condensed pollution.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and ADAM WU
item.media:description: The artist “Brother Nut” vacuuming the dust near the Beijing National Stadium on Nov. 15, Day 87 of his project to turn the city’s pollution into a tangible brick.

item.title: U.S. Marine Guilty in Killing of Transgender Woman in Philippines
item.description: Lance Cpl. Joseph Pemberton had been charged with murder, but the court convicted him of the lesser offense of homicide in the death of Jennifer Laude.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: Lance Cpl. Joseph Scott Pemberton of the United States Marines, center, being escorted into court in Olongapo City, Philippines, on Tuesday.

item.title: Long-Hidden Details Reveal Cruelty of 1972 Munich Attackers
item.description: Family members of the Israeli victims of Palestinian terrorists at the Munich Olympics are speaking openly in an effort to get their loved ones the recognition they believe is deserved.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: A Munich synagogue held the coffins of the victims of the attacks at the 1972 Olympics. Terrorists representing a branch of the Palestine Liberation Organization breached apartments housing Israeli athletes.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Dubious Carbon Budget
item.description: A climate “solution” based on magical thinking.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: OLIVER GEDEN

item.title: A Path for Climate Change, Beyond Paris
item.description: The emission pledges that countries have signaled they will make in Paris will inevitably fall short. What would a truly ambitious plan to tackle climate change look like?
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:credit: From Left, Francis Joseph Dean/Rex Features, via Associated Press; Carlos Barria, via Reuters; Stuart Palley for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, progress is being made in the use of wind turbines, solar panels and water treatment to create energy savings. But, the energy analyst Jesse Jenkins says, “I just don’t see a World War II-style mobilization happening for anything other than a world war.”

item.title: Burkina Faso Elects First New Leader in Decades
item.description: A former prime minister who has served in several high-ranking government positions emerged as the winner of the presidential election.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: HERVÉ TAOKO and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: Roch Marc Christian Kaboré waving to supporters after winning Burkina Faso's presidential election.

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Moscow Delays Enforcing Ban on Turkish Produce to Avoid Inflation
item.description: To prevent shortages, Russia said it would wait several weeks to carry out the ban, which was a response to the shooting down of a Russian warplane.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Turkey Returns Pilot’s Body
item.description: The Russian Air Force pilot was killed by ground fire while he parachuted from his warplane, which was shot down by Turkey on Nov. 24.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
